questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Yes -
The following list provides advantages to using aggregations:
Query performance over big data - as users interact with visuals on Power BI reports, DAX queries are submitted to the dataset. Boost query speeds by caching data at the aggregated level, using a fraction of the resources required at the detail level. Unlock big data in a way that would otherwise be impossible.

Box 2: Yes -
With Power BI Desktop, you can connect to many different types of data sources, then shape the data to meet your needs, enabling you to create visual reports to share with others. Shaping data means transforming the data: renaming columns or tables, changing text to numbers, removing rows, setting the first row as headers, and so on. Combining data means connecting to two or more data sources, shaping them as needed, then consolidating them into a useful query.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/desktop-aggregations https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/connect-data/desktop-shape-and-combine-data

comments.content: DataSet is a memory-resident representation of data that provides a consistent relational programming model regardless of the data source. So Report can have one DataSet that contains data from multiple source.

It's very meta, but I find questions like this on Fundamentals exams are almost a product flex--the answer is almost always "yes" (or the answer that indicates more capabilities/fewer limitations of the product in question)

discussion.content:
You can display aggregates and raw data in Power Bi Report.
Yes. Power BI allows you to display both aggregates and raw data in your reports. This gives you the flexibility to show different levels of detail to your users, depending on their needs. For example, you could show a summary of sales data for a region, as well as the raw data for each individual store.

You can display related data from multiple sources in the same Power bi report.
Yes. Power BI allows you to connect to multiple data sources and combine the data in your reports. This is a powerful feature that allows you to create more comprehensive and informative reports. For example, you could combine data from your sales database with data from your marketing database to create a report that shows how your marketing campaigns are affecting your sales.
If the raw data is already meet the requirement, therefore no need to clean up and you can publish it. So both answers are YES.
we cant represent raw data in pbi report we represent visuals which have abstract data or transformed data.

questions.question_text:
A company uses Microsoft Power Platform.

An administrator creates a new data loss prevention (DLP) policy.

You need to identify the Microsoft Power Platform components that must be updated to comply with the policy.

Which two types of components should you identify? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Provided answer is correct.

Power Automate cloud flows: These automated workflows can interact with various data sources and services. Ensuring that they adhere to DLP policies helps prevent accidental exposure of sensitive organizational data.

Canvas apps: These apps allow users to create custom interfaces for data entry and visualization. By enforcing DLP policies on canvas apps, you can prevent unintentional data leakage to unauthorized connectors or services.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/wp-data-loss-prevention
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/prevent-data-loss
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/create-dlp-policy

Selected Answer: AB
Based on Remko's post and link, A. Power Automate cloud flows and B. Canvas apps are clearly stated in Microsoft's Data loss prevention policies doc.

Selected Answer: AB
DLP policies are created in the Power Platform admin center. They affect Power Platform canvas apps and Power Automate flows. To create a DLP policy, you need to be a tenant admin or have the Environment Admin role.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/wp-data-loss-prevention
